dc:description: TWIST1 was first reported by Kim et al. in 2017 in relation to autosomal dominant Sweeney-Cox syndrome, a condition characterized by distinct facial dysostosis. Features include hypertelorism, deficiencies of the eyelids and facial bones, cleft palate/velopharyngeal insufficiency, and low-set cupped ears (PMID: 28369379). Three unique missense variants, all occurring de novo at the Glu117 codon, have been reported in patients (PMIDs: 28369379, 30450715). Evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level and experimental evidence. Of note, TWIST1 has also been assessed in association with Saethre-Chotzen syndrome and reached a definitive classification. Indicating it is an ultra-rare condition, only 3 cases of Sweeney-Cox syndrome have been published to date; therefore, there is limited but suggestive evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. While more evidence is needed to establish this relationship definitively, no convincing contradictory evidence has emerged. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Craniofacial malformation expert panel on 3/25/2021.

evidence.dc:description: Evidence was used to upgrade case-level data.
Multiple published probands have presented with imperforate anus, which is relevant to the phenotype observed in C. elegans.
evidence.rdfs:label: CRISPR/Cas9 in C. elegans

evidence.dc:description:
For arg-1::gfp, the fs2728, Glu29Asp, Glu29Val and Glu29Lys mutants did not express GFP in any cells whereas Glu29Gly, Glu29Ala, Glu29Gln expressed arg-1::gfp in the HMC and enteric muscles and a few Glu29Gly animals expressed it in the vulval muscles.

Nearly all homozygous animals, except for a few Glu29Gly and Glu29Gln animals, failed to express egl-15::gfp in the vulval muscles (or the precursor cells) compared with WT animals. Overall, these phenotypes indicated that Glu29Gly, Glu29Ala and Glu29Gln were the weakest alleles for transcriptional activation as they retained the ability to activate tissue-specific transcription of arg-1 (only in the HMC and enteric muscles) and to a much lesser extent Glu29Gly and Glu29Gln were able to activate expression of egl-15. 
 
Arg28Trp [representing SCS allees] animals could express egl-15::gfp indicating that these mutants are less severe than all the Glu29† mutants. These observations correlate with the unique clinical features present in Subjects 1 and 2 and reinforce that TWIST1-Glu117 mutations are causative of SwCoS.
evidence.rdfs:label: hlh-8 Glu29† mutant animals disrupt target gene expression

evidence.dc:description:
Expression patterns of Twist with those of Fgfr1, -2 and -3 were compared in the fetal mouse coronal suture over the course of embryonic days 14-18, as the suture is initiated and matures.

Twist expression precedes that of Fgfr genes at the time of initiation of the coronal suture
Twist is expressed by the mid-sutural mesenchyme cells. Twist expression domains show some overlap with those of Fgfr2, which is expressed in the most immature (proliferating) osteogenic tissue.
evidence.rdfs:label: Expression patters in fetal mouse coronal suture

evidence.dc:description: Twist is intensely expressed in murine head mesenchyme. At E10 transcripts are seen widely distributed in the first and second branchial arches, the surroundings of the developing eye and cranial mesenchyme below the epithelium, including that around Rathkes pouch
evidence.rdfs:label: Twist expression in murine head mesenchyme

evidence.dc:description: Missense variant that arose de novo with parental confirmation. Variant pathogenicity supported by functional evidence

evidence.rdfs:label: Subject 1
evidence.detectionMethod: Proband's parents were also sequenced and the variant was confirmed to be de novo
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: unusual scapulae with convex medial margins, normal phalanges, flattening of the occiput

evidence.dc:description: De novo missense variant. Variant pathogenicity supported by functional evidence

evidence.rdfs:label: Subject 2
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: both globes almost fully exposed, and fullness of the soft tissues in the glabellar region, , the fingers were held in a flexed position and were tapering, Patches of hair were present in an abnormal distribution on the back and below the knees bilaterally, persisting in tufts around the ankles to 6months of age.

evidence.dc:description: De novo missense variant with functional evidence supporting pathogenicity
